heading: out of africa
subheading: african dust does get around. a new study shows that a high proportion of the dust particles that americans breathe originated in africa.
author: reuters
text: dust blown across the atlantic ocean from africa makes up at least half the particles that americans in the southeast breathe in each day, researchers said on monday. on some days, the african dust can push the total number of airborne particles above the limit set by the environmental protection agency, joseph prospero of the university of miami said.reporting in the journal of geophysical research, prospero said the dust was nothing new.his 23-year study shows that, for instance, the soil in bermuda contains dust apparently from africa, while containing little dust with north american origins. but he said natural dust is often ignored in studies of airborne particulates.the epa's standard for particulate matter establishes how many bits of dust a person can safely breathe in. it covers particles measuring 2.5 microns or less in diameter, the size that can penetrate into the lung and cause damage leading to asthma, cancer, and other problems.sources can be dust, smoke, and other pollution. in his report prospero said pollution and the african dust hit their peaks at the same time -- during the summer.copyright
